results:
Siblings possessing telekinetic abilities (yes, you read that right) engage in a fierce competition, not just for the affection of Debra Winger, but also due to a long-held secret from their past that has caused a rift in their powers.

The film incorporates surreal elements (such as a fire brigade that acts as a singing Greek chorus), alongside moments of humor and romance. The soundtrack is phenomenal, reminiscent of how American Werewolf in London cleverly utilized popular werewolf-themed songs, except in this case, it's all about fire. And let me tell you, Dennis Quaid (oh, Dennis Quaid) rocking out to 'She's a lady' in his own trailer is an unforgettable scene.

By the way, one of the best lines from the movie is missing from the quoted section: 'Once you've experienced a clown, there's no turning back!'

I absolutely adore this film (I even imported the DVD from the US) and if the negative comments written by people who would prefer Legally Blonde 3 don't deter you, I highly recommend giving it a chance :)

results: It's fascinating how Ford chose lesser known actors for the supporting roles in 'Young Mr. Lincoln'. By doing so, he not only emphasizes the importance of Lincoln as the central character, but also allows the audience to gain a unique understanding of Lincoln's place and time. Like all of us, Lincoln was caught up in the issues and sentiments of his era, and he struggled to find his own path in resolving them. Ford doesn't rely solely on Fonda's words and actions as Lincoln, but rather, he tells the story of Lincoln's development through the expressions and reactions of the supporting cast. Through their interactions, we witness how the people responded to Lincoln's words and deeds, and how they placed their trust in him. If you shift your focus from Fonda to the supporting characters while watching 'Young Mr. Lincoln', you'll gain a deeper appreciation for both Lincoln and Ford. I even wonder if David Lean was inspired by Ford's approach when he directed Omar Sharif in 'Doctor Zhivago', as it is the reactions of the supporting characters that truly reveal Zhivago's character.
prompts:
Generate similar texts. Your answer must be in the same format as the examples. Text: It's remarkable that for 'Young Mr. Lincoln's' supporting players Ford cast lesser known, other-than-star actors. This not only heightens his film's focus on the central character of Lincoln, but it also affords the audience a refreshing insight into Lincoln as a man of his place and time, a man embroiled, as each one of us inexorably is, in the issues and sentiments of his time and seeking his way to resolving them. It's not so much through Fonda's Lincoln's words and actions but in the faces, the reactions of the supporting players that Ford tells the story of the formation of the young Lincoln's worldview, sense of place in society and polity, and of how the people responded to Mr. Lincoln's words and deeds and placed their trust in this man whom they deemed to have earned their respect and heeding.

Give this a try: instead of focusing on Henry Fonda, next time you view 'Young Mr. Lincoln' shift your focus to the supporting characters - you will, I expect, be handsomely rewarded with a more profound appreciation of both Lincoln and Ford. I like to suspect that Ford's storytelling through the supporting characters' reactions to Fonda's Lincoln may have appealed to David Lean when he directed Omar Sharif in 'Doctor Zhivago', in which it's the supporting characters' reactions to Zhivago that actually tell about Zhivago. Through their interactions, we witness how the people responded to Lincoln's words and deeds, and how they placed their trust in him.
